text: quinoa is often called the super grain
because it contains more protein than
any other grain out there it has all
eight essential amino acids so it's a
complete protein and it's high in
unsaturated fats and low in
carbohydrates it really is a superfood
and today I'm going to show you how to
make it now the kitchen conundrum here
is that most people make quinoa and it
turns out like this it's gummy and it's
kind of mushy and that's because
everybody's using a little bit too much
water these days I'm going to show you
how to do the process from start to
finish and you're going to end up with
fluffy delicious and tender quinoa now
before I get started there I want to
just walk you through the different
types of quinoa
we of course have white quinoa which is
the most common variety and you can find
this in any supermarket red quinoa is
starting to show up more on the shelves
and in specialty shops you should be
able to find this even in some really
great grocery stores you should be able
to find the red quinoa black quinoa is a
lot less common which I have here but is
very delicious and if you find it you
should definitely pick it up and then
there is kind of a rainbow blend of
white red and black quinoa now I'm just
going to use white quinoa here today and
what you have to do before you begin the
cooking process is you actually have to
rinse the quinoa off so I have some cold
water here one cup of quinoa and what
you have to do is give it a little swish
around in the water because there is a
bitter soapy resin that covers the seeds
of the quinoa quinoa is actually a seed
and you really have to wash it off
otherwise you will get that bitter taste
in the end and then make sure that you
drain your quinoa leave all of that
soapy cloudy water behind and now right
into a small saucepan I'm going to toast
the quinoa in a dry pan until the water
has evaporated and the quinoa starts to
pop and it will start to smell nutty and
that's when you know it's wonderfully
toasted and we're ready to add the water
to finish cooking it so you can see the
color difference now with this toasted
quinoa this is
the untoasted so it's much lighter and
it's nice and dark and nutty it's
starting to pop you can really smell
that nuttiness and now I'm going to add
the water typically when you look at
packages of quinoa the directions
usually say one cup of quinoa and two
cups of water but here I'm going to use
one and a half cups of water a lower
ratio of water so that we don't end up
with a mushy quinoa now you could use
chicken stock here you could use
vegetable stock if you wanted to add
more flavor I'm going to add a quarter
teaspoon of kosher salt give this a
quick stir and bring this up to a boil
I'm going to reduce the heat down to a
bare simmer cover this now and cook for
about 15 to 20 minutes until the water
has absorbed and the quinoa is nice and
plump
so the quinoa is cooked it's been
resting for about 10 minutes finishing
the steaming process you want to make
sure that you do not uncover it and
start stirring it throughout the process
whether it's cooking or its resting but
this resting stage is really important
because all of the water absorbs into
the grains and now what you should do is
gently fluff the quinoa almost like you
would a rice pilaf and you can see that
the grains are nice and separate it's
nice and fluffy it's not mushy and
clumpy like this version here and quinoa
is great in so many different things
whether it's a salad or it's a stuffing
one of my favorite ways to eat quinoa is
to actually make it with a little bit of
milk and have it with brown sugar and
some cinnamon in the morning as opposed
to oatmeal and there you have it the
foolproof way of making quinoa from
start to finish give it a try today
enjoy
you
